title: "King George's ""warm welcome home"" circular letter sent to returnees from Japan."
content:
accession_no_csv: 2017-00298

  Image: 

  object_work_type: letters (correspondence)

  title_text: \King George\u0027s \\warm welcome home\\ circular letter sent to returnees from Japan.\

  preference: main

  title_language: 

  creator_2: George R. I. (?)

  creator_1: George VI
 King of Great Britain
 1895-1952

  creator_role: authors

  creation_date: 1941-1945

  creation_place_original_location: Singapore Buckingham Palace (London
 England)

  inscriptions: 

  inscription_language: 

  shape: rectangular

  materials_name: paper (fiber product)

  techniques_name: writing (processes)

  object_colour: multicolored

  physical_appearance: This is a typed letter. The top of the letter has a red letterhead
 with an emblem and words \u0027BUCKINGHAM PALACE\u0027 printed on it. The letter is printed in black ink. There is date at the bottom-left of the letter. There is a signature in black ink on the bottom-right of the letter. The letter has a small fold on the lower-left corner. There are no tears seen.

  subject_terms_1: world wars prisoners of war

  subject_terms_2: World War
 1939-1945 George VI
 King of Great Britain
 1895-1952 Letters Prisoners of war

  subject_terms_3: 1942-1945 Japanese Occupation Letters war personalities

 1939-1945 1942-1945 Japanese Occupation

  context_7: Great Britain. Army. Royal Field Artillery

  context_8: armed forces

  sgcool_label_text: A letter issued to ex-prisoners of war of the Japanese
 in which George VI welcomes them home
 expressing sympathy for their “heavy… suffering” at the hands of the Japanese and wishes them and their families “a full measure of happiness”. This artefact is part of the archive of James Steele
 Royal Artillery (Field) who served in Malaya from January 1941-February 1942
 when interned as a P.O.W at Changi until his release in October 1945.

metadata.title_text: "King George's ""warm welcome home"" circular letter sent to returnees from Japan."

There is date at the bottom-left of the letter. There is a signature in black ink on the bottom-right of the letter. The letter has a small fold on the lower-left corner. There are no tears seen.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: A letter issued to ex-prisoners of war of the Japanese, in which George VI welcomes them home, expressing sympathy for their “heavy… suffering” at the hands of the Japanese and wishes them and their families “a full measure of happiness”. This artefact is part of the archive of James Steele, Royal Artillery (Field) who served in Malaya from January 1941-February 1942, when interned as a P.O.W at Changi until his release in October 1945.
